channel.title: [Java] How do I set the color to a new RGB Color
channel.description:
Okay, I have a color (java.awt.color). But I want to set it to a new Color without making a new Object of it. How on earth can I do that, if there is no setColor(or something similiar) method in its interface.
Because I'm making an applet which sees the color on the x and y positions of your mouse. And it shows the correct color, but everytime you move the mouse. It creates a new Color object, and that costs much memory.

item.title: [Java] How do I set the color to a new RGB Color
item.dc:creator: @Native1 Native^
item.description:
@Native1 wrote:

Well, my system now creates new color objects if you move the mouse, so it keeps making memory, wich is, if you move your mouse on a position with another color, useless. And yeah, then I should destroy those objects. But a good program should not depend on it’s garbage collector.
Sorry if it doesn’t make sense what I just said :P. But if there is no other way than creating new color objects. Then you’re right.

Read full topic
item.source: [Java] How do I set the color to a new RGB Color

item.title: [Java] How do I set the color to a new RGB Color
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

What makes you think setting the color of a color object to a NEW COLOR would be faster than creating a NEW COLOR, as long as you make sure to discard the old color?

Read full topic
